metadata.case_name: Non-Specific Low Back Pain - Office Worker
metadata.kngf_guideline_reference: KNGF Guideline on Low Back Pain (2013/2017)

patient_profile.name: Jan de Vries
patient_profile.living_situation: Lives with wife and two children (ages 8 and 12)
patient_profile.hobbies: Previously played tennis twice weekly, enjoys cycling with family
patient_profile.referral_reason: Low back pain for 6 weeks, no improvement with NSAIDs

presenting_complaint.chief_complaint: Low back pain that started 6 weeks ago after moving boxes during house renovation
presenting_complaint.pain_location: Central low back, sometimes radiating to right buttock
aggravating_factors: Getting out of bed in morning
easing_factors: Movement in general after initial stiffness
presenting_complaint.24_hour_pattern: Stiff and painful in morning (7/10), improves with movement, worsens by end of workday (6-7/10)
presenting_complaint.sleep_impact: Wakes 1-2 times per night when turning, takes 20 min to fall asleep due to discomfort

session_1_initial_encounter.patient_narrative: I hurt my back about 6 weeks ago when I was carrying boxes up the stairs during our house renovation. I felt a sharp pain in my lower back and had to stop. The next day I could barely move. My GP gave me ibuprofen and told me to rest. It got a bit better after a week, but now it's stuck at this level. I've been worried because my father had a disc herniation and needed surgery. I've stopped playing tennis and I'm scared to pick up my kids. At work, I can barely concentrate because of the pain after sitting for a while. My wife has to do more around the house and I feel guilty about that.

red_flags_screening.clinical_reasoning_note: No red flags identified. Trauma was minor and mechanism consistent with musculoskeletal origin.

yellow_flags_assessment.clinical_reasoning_note: Significant yellow flags present - fear-avoidance and catastrophizing are primary targets. Psychoeducation and graded activity essential.

past_medical_history.previous_lbp_episodes: One episode 5 years ago, resolved in 2 weeks with PT
past_medical_history.family_history: Father - lumbar disc herniation with surgery age 55

social_history.work_demands: Full-time office work, 8-9 hours sitting at desk, some flexibility to work from home
social_history.physical_activity_pre_injury: Tennis 2x/week, cycling with family on weekends
social_history.physical_activity_current: None - stopped all activities due to pain and fear
social_history.support_system: Supportive wife, but she is taking on more household responsibilities
social_history.stress_level: Moderate - deadline pressure at work, feels guilty about home situation

observation.posture_standing: Slight flattening of lumbar lordosis, guarded standing posture
observation.movement_quality: Moves cautiously, protects back during position changes
observation.gait: Normal, slightly reduced arm swing, shortened stride

flexion.pain: Yes - central LBP 6/10 at end range

extension.pattern: Limited but less painful than flexion

repeated_flexion_standing.effect: Pain increases, centralizes initially then peripheralizes with repetition

repeated_extension_standing.clinical_interpretation: Extension appears to be directional preference

repeated_extension_lying.effect: Pain centralizes to midline, 2/10 after 10 reps

slr.right: Hamstring tightness at 60 degrees, no radicular symptoms

neurological_screening.clinical_reasoning_note: No neurological deficits. SLR negative for radiculopathy. Buttock pain is likely referred pain from lumbar structures.

palpation.tenderness: Moderate tenderness L4-L5 paraspinals bilateral, more right than left
palpation.muscle_tone: Increased tone in erector spinae bilateral
palpation.trigger_points: Latent trigger points in gluteus medius right

special_tests.hip_rotation: Internal rotation limited to 25 degrees bilateral (normal 35-45)

sit_to_stand.observation: Uses arms to push up, forward trunk lean, guarded

picking_up_object_from_floor.observation: Avoids bending, squats stiffly with excessive caution

sustained_sitting_3_min.observation: Starts to shift and fidget after 90 seconds

tampa_scale_kinesiophobia.clinical_implication: Fear-avoidance behavior is significant barrier to recovery

body_functions.qualifier_description: Mild problem - suspected but needs assessment

participation_restrictions.qualifier_description: Severe problem - afraid to lift children

environmental_factors.qualifier_description: Mild facilitator - NSAIDs provide some relief

personal_factors.catastrophizing: Moderate - 'like my father who needed surgery'
personal_factors.previous_experience: Positive - previous episode resolved with PT
personal_factors.motivation: High - wants to return to sport and family activities
personal_factors.coping_style: Currently passive, but amenable to active approach

working_hypotheses.hypothesis: Non-specific low back pain with flexion-intolerant pattern
Lumbar disc involvement (not herniation with radiculopathy)
working_hypotheses.probability: Medium - possible disc bulge but no indication for imaging

excluded_hypotheses.reason: Negative SLR, no dermatomal pattern, no myotomal weakness, no reflex changes
No SI joint provocation tests performed yet, but pain pattern more consistent with lumbar origin

key_clinical_reasoning_questions.question: Why has this episode persisted beyond the typical 6-week recovery?
key_clinical_reasoning_questions.answer: Psychosocial factors (fear-avoidance, catastrophizing) and behavioral factors (stopped all activity, passive coping) are likely perpetuating factors.

key_clinical_reasoning_questions.question: What is the relationship between the tissue pathology and the disability?
key_clinical_reasoning_questions.answer: The disability (unable to work comfortably, no sport, can't lift children) is disproportionate to the tissue findings. Fear-avoidance is amplifying functional limitations.

key_clinical_reasoning_questions.question: Is imaging indicated?
key_clinical_reasoning_questions.answer: No - per KNGF guideline, imaging not indicated for non-specific LBP without red flags. Would reinforce illness beliefs.

problems.activity_limitation: Unable to sit for >30 minutes without significant increase in back pain (3/10 to 6/10)
problems.participation_impact: Limits work productivity and concentration at desk job

problems.activity_limitation: Unable to bend and lift objects >5kg from floor
problems.participation_impact: Cannot lift children, cannot perform household tasks

problems.activity_limitation: Not participating in any physical activity (tennis, cycling)
problems.participation_impact: Loss of recreation, reduced quality of life, family activities affected

long_term_goal.goal: Return to full participation in work and leisure activities including tennis and cycling with family, with manageable or minimal back pain (NPRS ≤2/10)

short_term_goals.goal: Sit at work desk for 60 minutes with pain ≤3/10, using microbreaks and posture strategies
Perform 10 prone press-ups 3x daily with pain centralizing and reducing to ≤2/10
Lift 10kg box from floor using proper mechanics with confidence and pain ≤3/10
short_term_goals.outcome_measure: Functional lifting test, PSFS lifting activity

short_term_goals.goal: Resume cycling with family for 30 minutes, pain ≤3/10
Return to tennis with appropriate warm-up, playing at 80% intensity with pain ≤2/10

intervention_plan.treatment_approach: Biopsychosocial, active approach with focus on education, fear-avoidance reduction, and graded activity
intervention_plan.kngf_guideline_alignment: Active interventions, patient education, no passive modalities for non-specific LBP

interventions.rationale: Address catastrophizing and fear-avoidance. Explain non-specific LBP, good prognosis, that hurt ≠ harm
key_messages: Your back is strong, not fragile
Your father's situation was different - you don't have the same condition
Movement is medicine - avoiding activity makes things worse
Imaging wouldn't change our approach and might increase worry

interventions.rationale: Extension centralized pain on examination. Directional preference for extension.
interventions.dosage: 10 reps every 2-3 hours, especially before and after prolonged sitting
interventions.evidence_level: Moderate - for patients with directional preference
interventions.progression: Progress to standing extension when able to maintain neutral spine

interventions.rationale: Address hypothesized core stability deficit, build confidence in spine loading
interventions.dosage: Start with low-load (dead bug, bird-dog), progress to functional loading
interventions.progression: Dead bug → Bird dog → Plank → Loaded movements

interventions.rationale: Walking is pain-free and builds confidence. Start successful exercise habit.
interventions.dosage: Start 15 min daily, increase 5 min/week to 30-45 min

interventions.rationale: Address kinesiophobia around lifting. Build confidence through successful experiences.
interventions.dosage: Start with light objects (2kg), practice proper mechanics, progressive loading
interventions.progression: 2kg object from table → 5kg from low surface → 10kg from floor → lifting children

interventions.rationale: Reduce sustained flexion loading at work, implement movement breaks
interventions.dosage: Microbreaks every 30 min (standing, walking, extension), workstation review

plan_of_care.frequency: 2x/week for first 2 weeks, then 1x/week for 4 weeks, then 2-weekly for final 4 weeks

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Spending too much time trying to identify exact tissue source rather than addressing modifiable factors
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: You've done a thorough physical exam. What modifiable factors (physical AND psychosocial) can you address that will help this patient return to function?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Recommending MRI to 'rule out disc herniation' despite no red flags
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: According to the KNGF guideline, when is imaging indicated for low back pain? What might be the unintended consequences of imaging in a patient with high fear-avoidance?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Treating this as purely biomechanical problem without addressing fear-avoidance
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: This patient's TSK is 44 and he's stopped all activity. How might his beliefs about his back be perpetuating his pain and disability?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Prescribing manual therapy, electrotherapy, or other passive modalities
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: What does the KNGF guideline say about passive treatments for non-specific LBP? How might passive treatment affect this patient's beliefs about his back?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Setting goals like 'improve lumbar flexion ROM' rather than functional goals
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: Your goal focuses on an impairment. What activity or participation does the patient want to achieve? Can you reframe this as a functional goal?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Advising patient to continue avoiding lifting, tennis, etc. 'until pain-free'
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: How might advising continued activity avoidance reinforce his fear-avoidance beliefs? What would a graded return to activity look like?

session_1.homework: Press-ups 10x every 2-3 hours, walking 15 min daily, posture breaks at work

session_2.expected_progress: Able to sit 45-60 min with strategy use, pain centralizing with press-ups

session_4.focus: Progress to functional activities, address fear of lifting
session_4.expected_progress: ODI improved 10-15 points, PSFS sitting improved, TSK showing improvement

session_8.focus: Return to sport planning, discharge planning
session_8.expected_outcomes: ODI <20%, PSFS all items >7, TSK <40, returned to cycling, ready for tennis

step_1_data_collection: What red flags did you screen for? Were any present?
What yellow flags did you identify? Why are these important?
How would you describe the patient's pain pattern (irritability, stage, nature)?
What information from the subjective exam influenced your physical examination choices?
step_2_problem_statements: Can you state the problem in terms of activity limitation first, then link to impairments?
How is the sitting limitation affecting his participation at work?
Is 'fear of movement' an impairment or something else? How do you classify it?
You've listed pain as a problem. How does pain CAUSE the activity limitations you've identified?
step_3_goal_setting: Is this goal written at the activity/participation level or impairment level?
Does this goal address what the PATIENT wants to achieve?
How will you measure if this goal has been achieved?
Is this goal realistic given the patient's current status and yellow flags?
step_4_intervention_selection: What is your evidence for choosing this intervention?
Does the KNGF guideline support this intervention for non-specific LBP?
How does this intervention address the fear-avoidance component?
Is this an active or passive intervention? What do guidelines recommend?
step_7_reevaluation: How will you know if treatment is working?
What outcome measures will you use to track progress?
If the patient isn't progressing as expected, what factors would you reassess?
When would you consider referring to another discipline?
